texts: “And, indeed, he may be against him, for all we know. To continue my surmises, Rayburn is the ‘Man in the Brown Suit.’ He read the paper he dropped. Misled by the dot as you were, he tries to reach Cabin 17 at one o’clock on the 22nd, after trying to acquire the cabin through Pagett. On the way, somebody stabs him.” “Who?” I asked. “Chichester. It all fits. Cable Lord Nasby that you’ve found ‘The Man in the Brown Suit,’ and your fortune’s made, Anne!” “You’ve overlooked several things.” “Such as?” “Rayburn has a scar, but it can be easily faked. He’s the right height and build. What’s the description of a head you pulverized them with at Scotland Yard?” I trembled. Suzanne was well-educated, but I hoped she didn’t know anthropology terms. “Dolichocephalic,” I said. Suzanne looked unsure. “Was that it?” “Yes. Long-headed. A head whose width is less than 75% of its length,” I explained. A pause followed. Just as I began to relax, Suzanne asked, “What’s the opposite?” “The opposite?” “There must be one. What do you call heads with breadth more than 75% of their length?” “Brachycephalic,” I reluctantly admitted. “I thought so.” “Did I? It was a mistake. I meant dolichocephalic,” I said confidently. Suzanne looked at me intently. “You lie very well, Gipsy girl. But tell me everything now.” “There’s nothing to tell,” I said. “Isn’t there?” Suzanne questioned gently. “I suppose I’ll have to tell you,” I said slowly. “I’m not ashamed. That’s what he did. He was rude and ungrateful, but I understand. I care horribly. Just seeing him has turned my life upside-down. I love him. I want him. I’ll walk all over Africa barefoot till I find him!” Suzanne studied me. “You’re very un-English, Gipsy girl. It’s something to care. But what a mercy for your little doctor man that you didn’t marry him.” “So no cabling to Lord Nasby?” I shook my head. “Yet you believe him innocent?” “I also believe innocent people can be hanged.” “He may have murdered her.” “No,” I said. “He didn’t.” “Sentiment.” “He wouldn’t strangle her with a bit of black cord. If he did it, he’d use his bare hands.” Suzanne shivered. “Beginning to see why you find him attractive!” I spoke to Colonel Race the next morning. “How’s the gipsy this morning? Longing for land?” I shook my head. “I’d like to stay on the sea forever.” We leaned over the rail. The sea was calm, with patches of color. “Interesting story last night,” I said. “Which one?” “The one about the diamonds.” “Of course women are interested in diamonds.” “What happened to the other young man?” “Young Lucas? He went to War and was reported Missing and Wounded believed killed.” That was all I needed to know. I wondered how much Colonel Race knew. I interviewed the night steward and got him to talk. “The lady wasn’t frightened, was she, miss? A harmless joke, a bet.” I got the story out of him.

He managed to get the case dismissed, but it resulted in two young men being ruined and disgraced. The old man's heart was shattered, and he disowned his son. The son, however, remained silent and indifferent to his father's accusations. A week later, war broke out and the two friends enlisted together, leading to a tragic end. The man revealed to Anne that his bitterness towards a woman was due to his friend's deep love for her, which ended in betrayal. After being reported dead in the war, he assumed a new identity and lived a numb existence until a chance encounter with a man from his past sparked his desire for justice. This man, Carton, confessed to his involvement in a robbery and revealed crucial information about the woman, Anita Grünberg. In order to clear his name, the man decided to confront Anita and make a deal with her, despite his lingering suspicions about Carton's honesty. Eventually, he uncovered Carton's deceit and embarked on a journey to England to seek the truth.

Poirot leaned back in his chair, his fingers tapping rhythmically on the armrest. "The case did not sit right with me," he remarked thoughtfully. "I was convinced from the start that we were up against a calculated, premeditated crime, carefully orchestrated by someone skilled in deception."

He, too, had inquired at the station. “And without doubt we are not original in the idea, Hastings. The excellent Giraud, he also has probably made his inquiries.” “You don’t think ” I said, and then stopped. “Ah, no, it would be too horrible!” Poirot looked inquiringly at me, but I said no more. It had just occurred to me that though there were seven women directly or indirectly connected with the case Mrs. Renauld, Madame Daubreuil and her daughter, the mysterious visitor, and the three servants there was, with the exception of old Auguste who could hardly count, only one man Jack Renauld. And a man must have dug a grave.… I had no time to develop further the appalling idea that had occurred to me, for Jack Renauld was ushered into the room. Poirot greeted him in a business-like manner. “Take a seat, monsieur. I regret infinitely to derange you, but you will perhaps understand that the atmosphere of the Villa is not too congenial to me. M. Giraud and I do not see eye to eye about everything. His politeness to me has not been striking and you will comprehend that I do not intend any little discoveries I may make to benefit him in any way.” “Exactly, M. Poirot,” said the lad. “That fellow Giraud is an ill-conditioned brute, and I’d be delighted to see some one score at his expense.” “Then I may ask a little favour of you?” “Certainly.” “I will ask you to go to the railway station and take a train to the next station along the line, Abbalac. Ask there at the cloak-room whether two foreigners deposited a valise there on the night of the murder. It is a small station, and they are almost certain to remember. Will you do this?” “Of course I will,” said the boy, mystified, though ready for the task. “I and my friend, you comprehend, have business elsewhere,” explained Poirot. “There is a train in a quarter of an hour, and I will ask you not to return to the Villa, as I have no wish for Giraud to get an inkling of your errand.” “Very well, I will go straight to the station.” He rose to his feet. Poirot’s voice stopped him. “One moment, M. Renauld, there is one little matter that puzzles me. Why did you not mention to M. Hautet this morning that you were in Merlinville on the night of the crime?” Jack Renauld’s face went crimson. With an effort he controlled himself. “You have made a mistake. I was in Cherbourg, as I told the examining magistrate this morning.” Poirot looked at him, his eyes narrowed, cat-like, until they only showed a gleam of green. “Then it is a singular mistake that I have made there for it is shared by the station staff. They say you arrived by the 11:40 train.” For a moment Jack Renauld hesitated, then he made up his mind. “And if I did? I suppose you do not mean to accuse me of participating in my father’s murder?” He asked the question haughtily, his head thrown back. “I should like an explanation of the reason that brought you here.” “That is simple enough. I came to see my fiancée, Mademoiselle Daubreuil. I was on the eve of a long voyage, uncertain as to when I should return. I wished to see her before I went, to assure her of my unchanging devotion.” “And you did see her?” Poirot’s eyes never left the other’s face. There was an appreciable pause before Renauld replied. Then he said: “Yes.” “And afterwards?” “I found I had missed the last train. I walked to St. Beauvais where I knocked up a garage and got a car to take me back to Cherbourg.” “St. Beauvais? That is fifteen kilometres. A long walk, M. Renauld.” “I I felt like walking.” Poirot bowed his head as a sign that he accepted the explanation. Jack Renauld took up his hat and cane and departed. In a trice Poirot jumped to his feet. “Quick, Hastings. We will go after him.” Keeping a discreet distance behind our quarry, we followed him through the streets of Merlinville. But when Poirot saw that he took the turning to the station, he checked himself. “All is well. He has taken the bait. He will go to Abbalac, and will inquire for the mythical valise left by the mythical foreigners. Yes, mon ami, all that was a little invention of my own.” “You wanted him out of the way!” I exclaimed. “Your penetration is amazing, Hastings! Now, if you please, we will go up to the Villa Geneviève.” “By the way, Poirot,” I said, as we walked along the hot white road, “I’ve got a bone to pick with you. I dare say you meant well, but really it was no business of yours to go mouching round to the Hôtel du Phare without letting me know.” Poirot shot a quick sidelong glance at me. “And how did you know I had been there?” he inquired. Much to my annoyance I felt the colour rising in my cheeks. “I happened to look in in passing,” I explained with as much dignity as I could muster. I rather feared Poirot’s banter, but to my relief, and somewhat to my surprise, he only shook his head with a rather unusual gravity. “If I have offended your susceptibilities in any way, I demand pardon of you. You will understand better soon. But, believe me, I have striven to concentrate all my energies on the case.” “Oh, it’s all right,” I said, mollified by the apology. “I know it’s only that you have my interests at heart. But I can take care of myself all right.” Poirot seemed to be about to say something further, but checked himself. Arrived at the Villa, Poirot led the way up to the shed where the second body had been discovered. He did not, however, go in, but paused by the bench which I have mentioned before as being set some few yards away from it. After contemplating it for a moment or two, he paced carefully from it to the hedge which marked the boundary between the Villa Geneviève and the Villa Marguerite. Then he paced back again, nodding his head as he did so. Returning again to the hedge, he parted the bushes with his hands. “With good fortune,” he remarked to me over his shoulder, “Mademoiselle Marthe may find herself in the garden. I desire to speak to her and would prefer not to call formally at the Villa Marguerite. Ah, all is well, there she is. Pst, mademoiselle! Pst! Un moment, s’il vous plaît.” I joined him at the moment that Marthe Daubreuil, looking slightly startled, came running up to the hedge at his call. “A little word with you, mademoiselle, if it is permitted?” “Certainly, Monsieur Poirot.” Despite her acquiescence, her eyes looked troubled and afraid. “Mademoiselle, do you remember running after me on the road the day that I came to your house with the examining magistrate? You asked me if any one were suspected of the crime.” “And you told me two Chilians.” Her voice sounded rather breathless, and her left hand stole to her breast. “Will you ask me the same question again, mademoiselle?” “What do you mean?” “This. If you were to ask me that question again, I should give you a different answer. Some one is suspected but not a Chilian.” “Who?” The word came faintly between her parted lips. “M. Jack Renauld.” “What?” It was a cry. “Jack? Impossible. Who dares to suspect him?” “Giraud.” “Giraud!” The girl’s face was ashy. “I am afraid of that man. He is cruel. He will he will ” She broke off. There was courage gathering in her face, and determination. I realized in that moment that she was a fighter. Poirot, too, watched her intently. “You know, of course, that he was here on the night of the murder?” he asked. “Yes,” she replied mechanically. “He told me.” “It was unwise to have tried to conceal the fact,” ventured Poirot. “Yes, yes,” she replied impatiently. “But we cannot waste time on regrets. We must find something to save him. He is innocent, of course, but that will not help him with a man like Giraud who has his reputation to think of. He must arrest some one, and that some one will be Jack.” “The facts will tell against him,” said Poirot. “You realize that?” She faced him squarely, and used the words I had heard her say in her mother’s drawing-room. “I am not a child, monsieur. I can be brave and look facts in the face. He is innocent, and we must save him.” She spoke with a kind of desperate energy, then was silent, frowning as she thought. “Mademoiselle,” said Poirot observing her keenly, “is there not something that you are keeping back that you could tell us?” She nodded perplexedly. “Yes, there is something, but I hardly know whether you will believe it it seems so absurd.” “At any rate, tell us, mademoiselle.” “It is this. M. Giraud sent for me, as an afterthought, to see if I could identify the man in there.” She signed with her head towards the shed. “I could not. At least I could not at the moment. But since I have been thinking ” “Well?” “It seems so queer, and yet I am almost sure. I will tell you. On the morning of the day M. Renauld was murdered, I was walking in the garden here, when I heard a sound of men’s voices quarrelling. I pushed aside the bushes and looked through. One of the men was M. Renauld and the other was a tramp, a dreadful looking creature in filthy rags. He was alternately whining and threatening. I gathered he was asking for money, but at that moment maman called me from the house, and I had to go. That is all, only I am almost sure that the tramp and the dead man in the shed are one and the same.” Poirot uttered an exclamation. “But why did you not say so at the time, mademoiselle?” “Because at first it only struck me that the face was vaguely familiar in some way. The man was differently dressed, and apparently belonged to a superior station in life. But tell me, Monsieur Poirot, is it not possible that this tramp might have attacked and killed M. Renauld, and taken his clothes and money?” “It is an idea, mademoiselle,” said Poirot slowly. “It leaves a lot unexplained, but it is certainly an idea. I will think of it.” A voice called from the house. “Maman,” whispered Marthe, “I must go.” And she slipped away through the trees. “Come,” said Poirot, and taking my arm, turned in the direction of the Villa. “What do you really think?” I asked, in some curiosity. “Was that story true, or did the girl make it up in order to divert suspicion from her lover?” “It is a curious tale,” said Poirot, “but I believe it to be the absolute truth. Unwittingly, Mademoiselle Marthe told us the truth on another point and incidentally gave Jack Renauld the lie. Did you notice his hesitation when I asked him if he saw Marthe Daubreuil on the night of the crime? He paused and then said ‘Yes.’ I suspected that he was lying. It was necessary for me to see Mademoiselle Marthe before he could put her on her guard. Three little words gave me the information I wanted. When I asked her if she knew that Jack Renauld was here that night, she answered ‘He told me.’ Now, Hastings, what was Jack Renauld doing here on that eventful evening, and if he did not see Mademoiselle Marthe whom did he see?” “Surely, Poirot,” I cried, aghast, “you cannot believe that a boy like that would murder his own father.” “Mon ami,” said Poirot, “you continue to be of a sentimentality unbelievable! I have seen mothers who murdered their little children for the sake of the insurance money! After that, one can believe anything.” “And the motive?” “Money of course. Remember that Jack Renauld thought that he would come in to half his father’s fortune at the latter’s death.” “But the tramp. Where does he come in?” Poirot shrugged his shoulders. “Giraud would say that he was an accomplice an apache who helped young Renauld to commit the crime, and who was conveniently put out of the way afterwards.” “But the hair round the dagger? The woman’s hair?” “Ah,” said Poirot, smiling broadly. “That is the cream of Giraud’s little jest. According to him, it is not a woman’s hair at all. Remember that the youths of today wear their hair brushed straight back from the forehead with pomade or hairwash to make it lie flat. Consequently some of the hairs are of considerable length.” “And you believe that too?” “No,” said Poirot with a curious smile. “For I know it to be the hair of a woman and more, which woman!” “Madame Daubreuil,” I announced positively. “Perhaps,” said Poirot, regarding me quizzically. But I refused to allow myself to get annoyed. “What are we going to do now?” I asked, as we entered the hall of the Villa Geneviève. “I wish to make a search amongst the effects of M. Jack Renauld. That is why I had to get him out of the way for a few hours.” “But will not Giraud have searched already?” I asked doubtfully. “Of course. He builds a case, as a beaver builds a dam, with a fatiguing industry. But he will not have looked for the things that I am seeking in all probability he would not have seen their importance if they stared him in the face. Let us begin.” Neatly and methodically, Poirot opened each drawer in turn, examined the contents, and returned them exactly to their places. It was a singularly dull and uninteresting proceeding. Poirot waded on through collars, pajamas and socks. A purring noise outside drew me to the window. Instantly I became galvanized into life. “Poirot!” I cried. “A car has just driven up. Giraud is in it, and Jack Renauld, and two gendarmes.” “Sacré tonnerre!” growled Poirot. “That animal of a Giraud, could he not wait? I shall not be able to replace the things in this last drawer with the proper method. Let us be quick.” Unceremoniously he tumbled out the things on the floor, mostly ties and handkerchiefs. Suddenly with a cry of triumph Poirot pounced on something, a small square cardboard, evidently a photograph. Thrusting it into his pocket, he returned the things pell-mell to the drawer, and seizing me by the arm dragged me out of the room and down the stairs. In the hall stood Giraud, contemplating his prisoner. “Good afternoon, M. Giraud,” said Poirot. “What have we here?” Giraud nodded his head towards Jack. “He was trying to make a getaway, but I was too sharp for him. He is under arrest for the murder of his father, M. Paul Renauld.” Poirot wheeled to confront the boy who leaned limply against the door, his face ashy pale. “What do you say to that, jeune homme?” Jack Renauld stared at him stonily. “Nothing,” he said. I was dumbfounded. Up to the last, I had not been able bring myself to believe Jack Renauld guilty. I had expected a ringing proclamation of his innocence when Poirot challenged him. But now, watching him as he stood, white and limp against the wall, and hearing the damning admission fall from his lips, I doubted no longer. But Poirot had turned to Giraud.

And with a smile and polite conversation, the peculiar man escorted the confused nobleman to the exit. Upon his return, he rubbed his hands gently. "Poirot," I inquired. "Have I lost my mind?" "No, my friend, but you are, as usual, lost in a mental haze." "How did you retrieve the diamond?" "From Mr. Rolf." "Rolf?" "Of course! The threatening letters, the Chinaman, the Society Gossip article, all were the creation of Mr. Rolf's cunning mind! The two identical diamonds, believed to be so rare, well! they were never real."

I could see that it was quite incompatible with his idea of my dignity. He looked shocked and pained. I had really had no intention of donning fancy dress, but the complete discomfiture of Pagett was too tempting to be forborne. "What do you mean?" I said. "Of course I shall wear fancy dress. So will you." Pagett shuddered. "So go down to the barber's and see about it," I finished. "I don't think he'll have any out sizes," murmured Pagett, measuring my figure with his eye. Without meaning it, Pagett can occasionally be extremely offensive. "And order a table for six in the saloon," I said. "We'll have the Captain, the girl with the nice legs, Mrs. Blair"   "You won't get Mrs. Blair without Colonel Race," Pagett interposed. "He's asked her to dine with him, I know." Pagett always knows everything. I was justifiably annoyed. "Who is Race?" I demanded, exasperated. As I said before, Pagett always knows everything or thinks he does. He looked mysterious again. "They say he's a Secret Service chap, Sir Eustace. Rather a great gun too. But of course I don't know for certain." "Isn't that like the Government?" I exclaimed. "Here's a man on board whose business it is to carry about secret documents, and they go giving them to a peaceful outsider, who only asks to be let alone." Pagett looked even more mysterious. He came a pace nearer and dropped his voice. "If you ask me, the whole thing is very queer, Sir Eustace. Look at that illness of mine before we started"   "My dear fellow," I interrupted brutally, "that was a bilious attack. You're always having bilious attacks." Pagett winced slightly. "It wasn't the usual sort of bilious attack. This time "For God's sake, don't go into the details of your condition, Pagett. I don't want to hear them." "Very well, Sir Eustace. But my belief is that I was deliberately poisoned!" "Ah!" I said. "You've been talking to Rayburn." He did not deny it. "At any rate, Sir Eustace, he thinks so and he should be in a position to know." "By the way, where is the chap?" I asked. "I've not set eyes on him since we came on board." "He gives out that he's ill, and stays in his cabin, Sir Eustace." Pagett's voice dropped again. "But that's camouflage, I'm sure. So that he can watch better." "Watch?"   "Over your safety, Sir Eustace. In case an attack should be made upon you." "You're such a cheerful fellow, Pagett," I said. "I trust that your imagination runs away with you. If I were you I should go to the dance as a death's head or an executioner. It will suit your mournful style of beauty." That shut him up for the time being. I went on deck. The Beddingfeld girl was deep in conversation with the missionary parson, Chichester. Women always flutter round parsons. A man of my figure hates stooping, but I had the courtesy to pick up a bit of paper that was fluttering round the parson's feet. I got no word of thanks for my pains. As a matter of fact, I couldn't help seeing what was written on the sheet of paper. There was just one sentence: "Don't try to play a lone hand or it will be the worse for you.

"There's a period after the 17. Why isn't there one after the 1 as well?" "There is a gap," I observed. "Yes, there is a gap, but..." Suddenly, she stood up and examined the paper closely under the light. There was a suppressed eagerness in her demeanor. "Anne, that isn't a period! It's a defect in the paper! A defect in the paper, do you understand? So you must disregard it, and focus only on the spaces, the spaces!" I stood up and positioned myself beside her.

"The case was kept under wraps to the best of their ability, and even today, people still speak of the strange series of deaths linked to the Tomb of Men-her-Ra as a sign of a long-gone king's revenge on those who violated his tomb a belief that, as Poirot mentioned to me, goes against all Egyptian beliefs and customs. “Poirot,” I suggested, “perhaps a change of scenery would do you good.” “You think so, my friend?” “I'm certain of it.” “Eh eh?” chuckled Poirot. “So it's settled, then?” “You'll come?” “And where might you be taking me?” “Brighton. A friend of mine in the City tipped me off to a great opportunity, and well, I have money to spare, as they say. I believe a weekend at the Grand Metropolitan would be just what the doctor ordered.” “Thank you, I graciously accept. You have a kind heart to think of an old man. And kindness, in the end, is more valuable than all the little grey cells. Yes, yes, I, who am speaking to you, am in danger of forgetting that sometimes.” I wasn't quite pleased with the implication. I have a feeling that Poirot occasionally underestimates my intelligence. In front of me, on the rough table, lies a letter from Suzanne. Dear Friends, I'm not surprised at all. Dear Anne, I couldn't resist writing. I'm sending you my diary. There's nothing for Race, but you might enjoy it. Use it for your writing. I suggest writing about the criminals I've met. The other day, while unpacking, I found a piece of the Daily Budget with "The Man in the Brown Suit." It feels like a lifetime ago. My son, playing in the sun, reminds me of the past. We studied the paper scrap intently. It was clearly a fragment of our target. A section of Baker's signature was visible, but no hint of the will's contents. The hospitals, yes; but one cannot suspect institutions." "Perhaps the old man changed his mind and destroyed it himself," I suggested. Poirot stood up, brushing off his knees meticulously. We rushed to the station immediately and barely caught a train to London, though not the main express. Poirot was dejected and dissatisfied. Before I could comprehend the situation, we were standing on the platform, hatless and without our bags, watching the train vanish into the darkness. I was livid. But Poirot paid no heed. "I left him to his gymnastic endeavours, and went on deck. As we came slowly into Boulogne Harbour Poirot appeared, neat and smiling, and announced to me in a whisper that Laverguier’s system had succeeded “to a marvel!” Japp’s forefinger was still tracing imaginary routes on his map. “Nonsense! The car started from Boulogne here they branched off. Now, my idea is that they transferred the Prime Minister to another car. See?” “Well,” said the tall detective, “I shall make for the seaports. Ten to one, they’ve smuggled him on board a ship.” Japp shook his head. “Too obvious. The order went out at once to close all the ports.” The day was just breaking as we landed. Major Norman touched Poirot on the arm. “There’s a military car here waiting for you, sir.” “Thank you, monsieur. But, for the moment, I do not propose to leave Boulogne.” “What?” “No, we will enter this hotel here, by the quay.” He suited the action to the word, demanded and was accorded a private room. We three followed him, puzzled and uncomprehending. He shot a quick glance at us. “It is not so that the good detective should act, eh? I perceive your thought. He must be full of energy. He must rush to and fro. He should prostrate himself on the dusty road and seek the marks of tyres through a little glass. He must gather up the cigarette-end, the fallen match? That is your idea, is it not?” His eyes challenged us. “But I Hercule Poirot tell you that it is not so! The true clues are within here!” He tapped his forehead. “See you, I need not have left London. It would have been sufficient for me to sit quietly in my rooms there. All that matters is the little grey cells within. Secretly and silently they do their part, until suddenly I call for a map, and I lay my finger on a spot so and I say: the Prime Minister is there! And it is so! With method and logic one can accomplish anything! This frantic rushing to France was a mistake it is playing a child’s game of hide-and-seek. But now, though it may be too late, I will set to work the right way, from within. Silence, my friends, I beg of you.” And for five long hours the little man sat motionless, blinking his eyelids like a cat, his green eyes flickering and becoming steadily greener and greener. The Scotland Yard man was obviously contemptuous, Major Norman was bored and impatient, and I myself found the time pass with wearisome slowness. Finally, I got up, and strolled as noiselessly as I could to the window. The matter was becoming a farce. I was secretly concerned for my friend. If he failed, I would have preferred him to fail in a less ridiculous manner. Out of the window I idly watched the daily leave boat, belching forth columns of smoke, as she lay alongside the quay. Suddenly I was aroused by Poirot’s voice close to my elbow."

I remember I tossed it into the rack at the side of the bunk.” She handed it to me. It was a standard round tin cylinder, the kind films are packed in for the tropics. I took it with a trembling hand, but as I did so, my heart skipped a beat. It was noticeably heavier than expected. With shaky fingers, I peeled off the strip of adhesive plaster that sealed it air-tight. I removed the lid, and a cascade of dull glassy pebbles spilled onto the bed. “Pebbles,” I said, disappointed. “Pebbles?” Suzanne exclaimed. The excitement in her voice thrilled me. “Pebbles? No, Anne, not pebbles! Diamonds!” Diamonds! I gazed, mesmerized, at the glassy heap on the bunk. I picked up a piece that, despite its weight, could have been a shard of a broken bottle. “Are you certain, Suzanne?” “Oh, absolutely, my dear. I’ve seen rough diamonds too many times to have any doubts. They're exquisite, Anne, and some of them are truly unique, I would say. There’s a story behind these.” “The story we heard tonight,” I interjected. “You mean?” “Colonel Race’s tale. It can’t be a mere coincidence. He shared it for a reason.” “To observe its impact, you think?” I nodded. “Its impact on Sir Eustace?” “Yes.” Yet, as the words left my lips, a doubt crept in. Was it Sir Eustace who was being tested, or was the story told for my benefit? I recalled the sense of being deliberately interrogated on that previous night. For some unknown reason, Colonel Race was suspicious. But how did he fit into all this? What possible link could he have to the situation? “Who is Colonel Race?” I inquired. “That’s quite the question,” Suzanne mused. “He’s known as a big-game hunter, and, as he mentioned tonight, he was distantly related to Sir Laurence Eardsley. I’ve never actually met him until this journey. He travels to and from Africa frequently. There’s a general belief that he does work for the Secret Service. I don’t know if it’s true. He’s certainly an enigmatic figure.” “I assume he inherited a substantial sum as Sir Laurence Eardsley’s heir?” “My dear Anne, he must be wealthy. He would make a splendid match for you.” “I can’t pursue him with you on board the ship,” I chuckled. “Oh, the woes of married women!” “We do have an advantage,” Suzanne said smugly. “And everyone knows how devoted I am to Clarence, my husband. It’s so safe and enjoyable to flirt with a devoted wife.” “Clarence must be thrilled to be married to someone like you.” “Well, I’m not the easiest to live with! Nonetheless, he can always retreat to the Foreign Office, where he adjusts his eyeglass and dozes off in a large armchair. We could send him a cable to gather all the information he has on Race."

Harry listened intently. “He saw a man leaving Sir Eustace’s cabin and followed him to the deck. Is that what he said? Now, who had the cabin opposite Sir Eustace? Colonel Race. The words were cryptic and significant. Could it be that she knew more than we assumed? She had denied any knowledge of the mysterious task her husband had supposedly entrusted to their son. But was she truly as clueless as she pretended? Could she provide answers if she wanted to, and was her silence part of a calculated and premeditated plan? The more I pondered on it, the more convinced I became that I was onto something. Mrs. Renauld was privy to more than she let on. Her surprise at seeing her son had momentarily given her away. I was certain that she knew, if not the perpetrators, at least the reason behind the crime. But there must be some powerful reasons keeping her quiet. I shared my thoughts with him, confident in my deductions but half-expecting him to mock my suspicions. To my surprise, he nodded thoughtfully. "You're absolutely right, Hastings. I've always had a feeling that she was hiding something. Initially, I suspected her, if not of planning, at least of being complicit in the crime." "You suspected her?" I exclaimed. "Indeed! She stands to benefit greatly, in fact, she's the sole beneficiary of this new will. So, naturally, she drew my attention from the start. You may have noticed that I took an early opportunity to examine her wrists. I wanted to see if there was a chance that she had tied herself up. Well, I could tell immediately that it wasn't staged, the ropes had actually cut into her flesh. That ruled out the possibility of her acting alone. But it was still plausible for her to have been involved, or to have been the mastermind with an accomplice. Furthermore, her account, as she narrated it, seemed oddly familiar to me - the masked assailants she couldn't identify, the mention of 'the secret' - all of it sounded like something I had heard, or read, before. Her evidence was mainly concerned with the discovery of her mistress gagged and bound, of which she gave rather an exaggerated account. She, like Françoise, had heard nothing during the night. "It is, of course, possible," said the magistrate smoothly. "Now, my girl, was it you who admitted Madame Daubreuil to the house last night?" "Not last night, monsieur, the night before." "But Françoise has just told us that Madame Daubreuil was here last night?" "No, monsieur. A lady did come to see M. Renauld last night, but it was not Madame Daubreuil." Surprised, the magistrate insisted, but the girl held firm. She knew Madame Daubreuil perfectly by sight. This lady was dark also, but shorter, and much younger. Nothing could shake her statement. "Had you ever seen this lady before?" "Never, monsieur." And then the girl added diffidently: "But I think she was English." "English?" "Yes, monsieur. She asked for M. She gazed at me, laughed lightly and remarked: “Anne, you truly are an extraordinary girl. Have you ever experienced any misgivings?” “Misgivings?” I inquired, confused. “Yes, misgivings, misgivings, misgivings! Setting off alone with hardly any money. What will you do when you find yourself in a foreign land with no money left?” “There’s no point in worrying about that until it happens. I still have plenty of money. The twenty-five pounds from Mrs. Flemming is still intact, and I won in the sweepstakes yesterday. That’s another fifteen pounds. I have quite a bit of money. Forty pounds!” “A lot of money! Goodness!” murmured Mrs. Blair. “I couldn’t do it, Anne, and I consider myself brave in my own way. I couldn’t start off cheerfully with a few pounds in my pocket and no idea of what I was doing or where I was going.” “But that’s the thrill of it,” I exclaimed, feeling stirred. “It gives one such a wonderful sense of adventure.” She glanced at me, nodded a few times, and then grinned. “Lucky Anne! Not many people in the world share your feelings.” “Well,” I said impatiently, “what do you think of this, Mrs. Blair?” “I think it’s the most exciting thing I’ve ever heard! Now, let’s get to the point. You mentioned in Sir Eustace’s secretary, not that solemn Pagett, the other one you identified the man who was stabbed and sought refuge in your cabin?” I nodded. “That gives us two connections linking Sir Eustace to this mess. The woman was killed in his house, and it’s his secretary who gets stabbed at one o’clock. I don’t suspect Sir Eustace himself, but it can’t all be a coincidence. There must be a link somewhere, even if he's unaware of it.” "Then there’s the strange case of the stewardess,” she continued thoughtfully. “What did she look like?” “I barely noticed her. I was so excited and a stewardess seemed so inconsequential. But yes, her face did seem familiar. It could be because I saw her around the ship.” “Her face seemed familiar to you,” Suzanne said. “Are you sure she wasn’t a man?” “She was quite tall,” I admitted. “Hmm. Unlikely to be Sir Eustace, I’d say, nor Mr. Pagett. Wait!” She grabbed a piece of paper and started drawing rapidly. She examined the result with her head tilted to one side. “A striking resemblance to the Rev. Edward Chichester. Now onto the etceteras.” She handed me the paper. “Is this your stewardess?” “Yes,” I exclaimed. “Suzanne, how clever of you!” She dismissed the compliment with a casual gesture. “I’ve always had suspicions about that Chichester character. Do you recall how he dropped his coffee cup and turned pale when we were discussing Crippen the other day?” “And he tried to get Cabin 17!” “Yes, it all fits in so far. But what does it all mean? What was supposed to happen at one o’clock in Cabin 17? It can’t be the stabbing of the secretary. Timing that for a specific hour on a specific day in a specific place would serve no purpose. No, it must have been some kind of appointment and he was on his way to keep it when they stabbed him. But who was the appointment with? Certainly not with you. It might have been with Chichester. Or it might have been with Pagett.” “That seems unlikely,” I objected, “they can see each other any time.” We both fell silent for a moment, then Suzanne took a different approach. “Could there have been something hidden in the cabin?” “That seems more plausible,” I agreed. “It would explain why my things were ransacked the next morning. But there was nothing hidden there, I’m certain of it.” “The young man couldn’t have slipped something into a drawer the night before?” I shook my head. “I would have noticed.” “Could it have been your precious piece of paper they were searching for?” “It’s a possibility, but it seems rather pointless. It was only a time and a date, and both had already passed.” Suzanne nodded. “That makes sense. No, it wasn’t the paper. By the way, do you have it with you? I’d like to see it.” I had brought the paper with me as Exhibit A, and I handed it to her. She examined it, frowning. “There’s a dot after the 17. Why isn’t there a dot after the 1 too?” “There’s a space,” I pointed out. “Yes, there’s a space, but” Suddenly she stood up and scrutinized the paper under the light. There was a suppressed excitement in her demeanor. “Anne, that isn’t a dot! It’s a flaw in the paper! A flaw in the paper, do you see? So you must ignore it, and just go by the spaces the spaces!” I stood beside her. I read out the figures as I now perceived them. “1 71 22.” “You see,” said Suzanne, “it’s the same, but not exactly. It’s still one o’clock, and the 22nd but it’s Cabin 71! My cabin, Anne!” We stared at each other, elated with our new discovery and so immersed in excitement that one might think we had solved the entire mystery. Then I came back to reality with a jolt. “But, Suzanne, nothing happened here at one o’clock on the 22nd?” Her expression mirrored my disappointment. “No, it didn’t.” Another thought struck me. “This isn’t your original cabin, is it, Suzanne? I mean not the one you initially booked?” “No, the purser reassigned me to it.” “I wonder if it was reserved before departure for someone who didn’t show up. We could find out.” “We don’t need to find out, Gipsy girl,” exclaimed Suzanne. “I know! The purser told me about it. The cabin was reserved in the name of Mrs. Grey but it turns out that Mrs. Grey was actually a pseudonym for the renowned Madame Nadina. She’s a famous Russian dancer. She’s never performed in London, but Paris has been captivated by her. She had a tremendous success there during the War. A rather questionable character, I hear, but very charming. The purser expressed his regrets that she wasn’t on board very sincerely when he assigned me her cabin, and then Colonel Race informed me a lot more about her. It seems there were some strange rumors circulating in Paris. She was suspected of espionage, but they had no evidence. I believe Colonel Race was there solely for that reason. He’s divulged some fascinating details to me. There was a well-organized group, not of German origin at all. In fact, the leader, often referred to as ‘the Colonel,’ was believed to be English, but they never uncovered his identity. However, he clearly controlled a significant network of international criminals. Robberies, espionage, assaults, he orchestrated them all and usually pinned the blame on an innocent scapegoat. Diabolically clever, he must have been! This woman was rumored to be one of his operatives, but they couldn’t find anything concrete. Yes, Anne, we're on the right track. Nadina is exactly the type to be involved in this scheme. The meeting on the morning of the 22nd was with her in this cabin. But where is she? Why didn’t she embark?” A realization dawned on me. “She intended to set sail,” I said slowly. “Then why didn’t she?” “Because she was dead. Suzanne, Nadina was the woman murdered in Marlow!” My thoughts drifted back to the empty room in the desolate house, and once again I felt that ominous sense of danger and malevolence. Along with it came the recollection of the falling pencil and the discovery of the roll of films. A roll of films that struck a more recent chord. Where had I heard of a roll of films? And why did I connect that thought with Mrs. Blair? Suddenly, I dashed towards her and nearly shook her in my excitement. “Your films! The ones that were passed to you through the ventilator? Wasn’t that on the 22nd?” “The ones I lost?” “How do you know they were the same? Why would anyone return them to you like that in the middle of the night? It’s an absurd idea. No, they were a message, the films had been removed from the yellow tin case, and something else placed inside. Do you still have it?” “I might have used it. Oh, here it is. I remember I tossed it into the rack at the side of the bunk.” She handed it to me. It was a standard round tin cylinder, typically used for films in tropical environments. I took it with trembling hands, but as I did so, my heart skipped a beat. It felt heavier than it should have been. With quivering fingers, I peeled off the strip of adhesive tape that sealed it shut. I removed the lid, and a cascade of dull, glassy stones spilled onto the bed. “Stones,” I said, feeling disappointed. “Stones?” exclaimed Suzanne. The excitement in her voice spurred me on. “Stones? No, Anne, not stones! Diamonds!” Diamonds! I stared, captivated, at the glimmering pile on the bunk. I picked up one that, despite its weight, resembled a shard of a broken bottle. “Are you certain, Suzanne?” “Oh, yes, my dear. I’ve seen raw diamonds too many times to have any doubts. They’re exquisite, Anne, and some of them are truly unique, I would say. There’s a story behind these.” “The story we heard tonight,” I exclaimed. “You mean?” “Colonel Race's account. It can’t be a coincidence. He recounted it for a reason.” “To observe its impact, you think?” I nodded. “Its effect on Sir Eustace?” “Yes.” But even as I said it, a doubt crept in. Was it Sir Eustace who was being tested, or was the story told for my benefit? I recalled the feeling of being deliberately interrogated on a previous night. Colonel Race was suspicious for some reason. But how did he fit into the puzzle? What was his connection to this affair? “Who is Colonel Race?” I inquired. “That’s a bit of a mystery,” Suzanne remarked. “He’s known for big-game hunting, and, as you heard him say tonight, he was a distant relative of Sir Laurence Eardsley. I never met him until this voyage. He travels to and from Africa quite often. There's a notion that he does work for the Secret Service. I’m not sure if it’s true. He’s quite an enigmatic figure.” “He must have inherited a substantial sum from Sir Laurence Eardsley?” “My dear Anne, he must be quite wealthy. You know, he’d be a perfect match for you.” “I can’t pursue him with you on board the ship,” I joked. “Oh, these married women!” “We do have an advantage,” Suzanne said smugly. “And everyone knows that I am entirely devoted to my husband, Clarence, you know. It’s so secure and pleasant to be involved with a loyal wife.” “It must be lovely for Clarence to be married to someone like you.” “Well, I’m tolerable to live with! Still, he can always escape to the Foreign Office, where he adjusts his eyeglass and dozes off in a large armchair. We could cable him to ask about Colonel Race. I love sending cables. And they irritate Clarence so. He always says a letter would suffice. I doubt he’d share much, though. He’s incredibly discreet. That’s what makes him so challenging to live with for extended periods. But let’s continue with our matchmaking. I’m certain Colonel Race is quite taken with you, Anne. Just give him a couple of glances with those mischievous eyes of yours, and it’s a done deal. Everyone gets engaged on board ship. There’s nothing else to do.” “I’m not looking to get married.” “Are you not?” Suzanne asked. “Why not? I adore being married, even to Clarence!” I disregarded her lightheartedness. “What I want to know is,” I said firmly, “what is Colonel Race's involvement in this? He’s part of it somehow.” “You don’t think it was mere chance, him sharing that story?” “No, I don’t,” I stated decisively. “He was observing us all closely. Some of the diamonds were recovered, not all. Perhaps these are the missing ones or perhaps” “Perhaps what?” I didn’t respond directly. “I’d like to know,” I said, “what happened to the other young man. Not Eardsley, but what was his name? Lucas!” “We’re shedding some light on the situation, at least. It's the diamonds that all these people are after. It must have been to acquire the diamonds that ‘The Man in the Brown Suit’ murdered Nadina.” “He didn’t kill her,” I interjected. “Of course he did. Who else could have?” “I’m not sure. But I believe he didn’t kill her.” “He entered that house three minutes after her and emerged as pale as a sheet.” “Because he found her dead.” “But no one else entered.” “Then the murderer was already in the house, or found another way in. He didn’t need to pass the lodge, he could have climbed over the wall.” Suzanne glanced at me sharply. “‘The Man in the Brown Suit,’” she mused. “Who was he, I wonder? In any case, he was the same as the ‘doctor’ in the Tube. He would have had the time to remove his disguise and follow the woman to Marlow. She and Carton were meant to meet there, they both had a viewing appointment for the same house, and if they took such elaborate precautions to make their meeting seem accidental, they must have suspected they were being followed. Nonetheless, Carton didn’t realize that his shadow was the ‘Man in the Brown Suit.’ When he recognized him, the shock was so great that he lost his composure completely and stepped back onto the line. It all seems quite clear, don’t you think, Anne?” I remained silent. “Yes, that’s how it happened. He took the paper from the deceased man, and in his haste to escape, he dropped it. Then he followed the woman to Marlow. What did he do after he left there, after he killed her or, as you believe, found her dead. Where did he go?” Still, I said nothing. “I wonder,” Suzanne said thoughtfully. “Is it possible that he persuaded Sir Eustace Pedler to bring him on board as his secretary? It would be an excellent chance to leave England safely and evade capture. But how did he persuade Sir Eustace? It seems like he had some leverage over him.” “Or over Pagett,” I suggested involuntarily. “You don’t seem to have a liking for Pagett, Anne. Sir Eustace claims he’s a diligent and skilled young man. And, in truth, he may be in his favor. Well, to continue my speculations. Rayburn is the ‘Man in the Brown Suit.’ He read the paper he dropped. Consequently, misled by the dot like you were, he tried to reach Cabin 17 at one o’clock on the 22nd, after previously attempting to secure the cabin through Pagett. On the way there, someone attacked him” “Who?” I interrupted. “Chichester. Yes, it all fits. Cable Lord Nasby that you’ve found ‘The Man in the Brown Suit,’ and you’re set for life, Anne!” “There are a few things you've overlooked.” “What things? Rayburn has a scar, I know, but a scar can be easily falsified.”

"Poirot,” I cried, “what more do you know?” “Mon ami, you must make your own deductions. You have ‘access to the facts!’ Concentrate your grey cells. Reason not like Giraud but like Hercule Poirot.” “But are you sure?” “My friend, in many ways I have been an imbecile. But at last I see clearly.” “You know everything?” “I have discovered what M. Renauld sent for me to discover.” “And you know the murderer?” “I know one murderer.” “What do you mean?” “We talk a little at cross-purposes. There are here not one crime, but two. The first I have solved, the second eh bien, I will confess, I am not sure!” “But, Poirot, I thought you said the man in the shed had died a natural death?” “Ta-ta-ta.” Poirot made his favourite ejaculation of impatience. “Still you do not understand. One may have a crime without a murderer, but for two crimes it is essential to have two bodies.” His remark struck me as so peculiarly lacking in lucidity that I looked at him in some anxiety. But he appeared perfectly normal. Suddenly he rose and strolled to the window. “Here he is,” he observed. “Who?” “M. Jack Renauld. I sent a note up to the Villa to ask him to come here.” That changed the course of my ideas, and I asked Poirot if he knew that Jack Renauld had been in Merlinville on the night of the crime. I had hoped to catch my astute little friend napping, but as usual, he was omniscient. He, too, had inquired at the station. “And without doubt we are not original in the idea, Hastings. The excellent Giraud, he also has probably made his inquiries.” “You don’t think ” I said, and then stopped. “Ah, no, it would be too horrible!” Poirot looked inquiringly at me, but I said no more. It had just occurred to me that though there were seven women directly or indirectly connected with the case Mrs. Renauld, Madame Daubreuil and her daughter, the mysterious visitor, and the three servants there was, with the exception of old Auguste who could hardly count, only one man Jack Renauld. And a man must have dug a grave.… I had no time to develop further the appalling idea that had occurred to me, for Jack Renauld was ushered into the room. Poirot greeted him in a business-like manner. “Take a seat, monsieur. I regret infinitely to derange you, but you will perhaps understand that the atmosphere of the Villa is not too congenial to me. M. Giraud and I do not see eye to eye about everything. (Extract from the diary of Sir Eustace Pedler) There is something to be said for life on board ship. It is peaceful. My grey hairs fortunately exempt me from the indignities of bobbing for apples, running up and down the deck with potatoes and eggs, and the more painful sports of “Brother Bill” and Bolster Bar. What amusement people can find in these painful proceedings has always been a mystery to me. But there are many fools in the world. One praises God for their existence and keeps out of their way. Fortunately I am an excellent sailor. Pagett, poor fellow, is not. He began turning green as soon as we were out of the Solent. I presume my other so-called secretary is also sea-sick. At any rate he has not yet made his appearance. But perhaps it is not sea-sickness, but high diplomacy. The great thing is that I have not been worried by him. On the whole, the people on board are a mangy lot. Only two decent Bridge players and one decent-looking woman Mrs. Clarence Blair. I’ve met her in town of course. She is one of the only women I know who can lay claim to a sense of humour. I enjoy talking to her, and should enjoy it more if it were not for a long-legged taciturn ass who has attached himself to her like a limpet. I cannot think that this Colonel Race really amuses her. He’s good-looking in his way, but dull as ditch water. One of these strong silent men that lady novelists and young girls always rave over. Guy Pagett struggled up on deck after we left Madeira and began babbling in a hollow voice about work. What the devil does any one want to work for on board ship? It is true that I promised my publishers my “Reminiscences” early in the summer, but what of it? Who really reads reminiscences? Old ladies in the suburbs. And what do my reminiscences amount to? I’ve knocked against a certain number of so-called famous people in my lifetime. With the assistance of Pagett, I invent insipid anecdotes about them. And, the truth of the matter is, Pagett is too honest for the job. He won’t let me invent anecdotes about the people I might have met but haven’t. I tried kindness with him. “You look a perfect wreck still, my dear chap,” I said easily. “What you need is a deck-chair in the sun. No not another word. The work must wait.” The next thing I knew he was worrying about an extra cabin. “There’s no room to work in your cabin, Sir Eustace. It’s full of trunks.” From his tone, you might have thought that trunks were blackbeetles, something that had no business to be there. I explained to him that, though he might not be aware of the fact, it was usual to take a change of clothing with one when travelling. He gave the wan smile with which he always greets my attempts at humour, and then reverted to the business in hand. “And we could hardly work in my little hole.” I know Pagett’s “little holes” he usually has the best cabin on the ship. “I’m sorry the Captain didn’t turn out for you this time,” I said sarcastically. “Perhaps you’d like to dump some of your extra luggage in my cabin?” Sarcasm is dangerous with a man like Pagett. He brightened up at once. “Well, if I could get rid of the typewriter and the stationery trunk” The stationery trunk weighs several solid tons. It causes endless unpleasantness with the porters, and it is the aim of Pagett’s life to foist it on me. It is a perpetual struggle between us. He seems to regard it as my special personal property. I, on the other hand, regard the charge of it as the only thing where a secretary is really useful. “We’ll get an extra cabin,” I said hastily. The thing seemed simple enough, but Pagett is a person who loves to make mysteries. He came to me the next day with a face like a Renaissance conspirator. “You know you told me to get Cabin 17 for an office?” “Well, what of it? Has the stationery trunk jammed in the doorway?” “The doorways are the same size in all the cabins,” replied Pagett seriously. “But I tell you, Sir Eustace, there’s something very queer about that cabin.” Memories of reading The Upper Berth floated through my mind. “If you mean that it’s haunted,” I said, “we’re not going to sleep there, so I don’t see that it matters. Ghosts don’t affect typewriters.” Pagett said that it wasn’t a ghost, and that, after all, he hadn’t got Cabin 17. He told me a long, garbled story. Apparently he, and a Mr. Chichester, and a girl called Beddingfeld, had almost come to blows over the cabin. Needless to say, the girl had won, and Pagett was apparently feeling sore over the matter. “Both 13 and 28 are better cabins,” he reiterated. “But they wouldn’t look at them.” “Well,” I said, stifling a yawn, “for that matter, no more would you, my dear Pagett.” He gave me a reproachful look. “You told me to get Cabin 17.” There is a touch of the “boy upon the burning deck” about Pagett. “My dear fellow,” I said testily, “I mentioned No. 17 because I happened to observe that it was vacant. But I didn’t mean you to make a stand to the death about it 13 or 28 would have done us equally well.” He looked hurt. “There’s something more, though,” he insisted. “Miss Beddingfeld got the cabin, but this morning I saw Chichester coming out of it in a furtive sort of way.” I looked at him severely. “If you’re trying to get up a nasty scandal about Chichester, who is a missionary though a perfectly poisonous person and that attractive child, Anne Beddingfeld, I don’t believe a word of it,” I said coldly. “Anne Beddingfeld is an extremely nice girl with particularly good legs. I should say she had far and away the best legs on board.” Pagett did not like my reference to Anne Beddingfeld’s legs. He is the sort of man who never notices legs himself or, if he does, would die sooner than say so. Also he thinks my appreciation of such things frivolous. I like annoying Pagett, so I continued maliciously: “As you’ve made her acquaintance, you might ask her to dine at our table to-morrow night. It’s the Fancy Dress dance. By the way, you’d better go down to the barber and select a fancy costume for me.” “Surely you will not go in fancy dress?” said Pagett, in tones of horror. I could see that it was quite incompatible with his idea of my dignity. He looked shocked and pained. I had really had no intention of donning fancy dress, but the complete discomfiture of Pagett was too tempting to be forborne. “What do you mean?” I said. “Of course I shall wear fancy dress. So will you.” Pagett shuddered. “So go down to the barber’s and see about it,” I finished. “I don’t think he’ll have any out sizes,” murmured Pagett, measuring my figure with his eye. Without meaning it, Pagett can occasionally be extremely offensive. “And order a table for six in the saloon,” I said. “We’ll have the Captain, the girl with the nice legs, Mrs. Blair” “You won’t get Mrs. Blair without Colonel Race,” Pagett interposed. “He’s asked her to dine with him, I know.” Pagett always knows everything. I was justifiably annoyed. “Who is Race?” I demanded, exasperated. As I said before, Pagett always knows everything or thinks he does. He looked mysterious again. “They say he’s a Secret Service chap, Sir Eustace. Rather a great gun too. But of course I don’t know for certain.” “Isn’t that like the Government?” I exclaimed. “Here’s a man on board whose business it is to carry about secret documents, and they go giving them to a peaceful outsider, who only asks to be let alone.” Pagett looked even more mysterious. He came a pace nearer and dropped his voice. “If you ask me, the whole thing is very queer, Sir Eustace. Look at that illness of mine before we started” “My dear fellow,” I interrupted brutally, “that was a bilious attack. You’re always having bilious attacks.” Pagett winced slightly. “It wasn’t the usual sort of bilious attack. This time “For God’s sake, don’t go into the details of your condition, Pagett. I don’t want to hear them.” “Very well, Sir Eustace. But my belief is that I was deliberately poisoned!” “Ah!” I said. “You’ve been talking to Rayburn.” He did not deny it. “At any rate, Sir Eustace, he thinks so and he should be in a position to know.” “By the way, where is the chap?” I asked. “I’ve not set eyes on him since we came on board.” “He gives out that he’s ill, and stays in his cabin, Sir Eustace.” Pagett’s voice dropped again. “But that’s camouflage, I’m sure. So that he can watch better.” “Watch?” “Over your safety, Sir Eustace. In case an attack should be made upon you.” “You’re such a cheerful fellow, Pagett,” I said. “I trust that your imagination runs away with you. If I were you I should go to the dance as a death’s head or an executioner. It will suit your mournful style of beauty.” That shut him up for the time being. I went on deck. The Beddingfeld girl was deep in conversation with the missionary parson, Chichester. Women always flutter round parsons. A man of my figure hates stooping, but I had the courtesy to pick up a bit of paper that was fluttering round the parson’s feet. I got no word of thanks for my pains. As a matter of fact, I couldn’t help seeing what was written on the sheet of paper. There was just one sentence: “Don’t try to play a lone hand or it will be the worse for you.” That’s a nice thing for a parson to have. Who is this fellow Chichester, I wonder? He looks mild as milk. But looks are deceptive. I shall ask Pagett about him. Pagett always knows everything. I sank gracefully into my deck-chair by the side of Mrs. Blair, thereby interrupting her tête-à-tête with Race, and remarked that I didn’t know what the clergy were coming to nowadays. Then I asked her to dine with me on the night of the Fancy Dress dance. Somehow or other Race managed to get included in the invitation. After lunch the Beddingfeld girl came and sat with us for coffee. I was right about her legs. They are the best on the ship. I shall certainly ask her to dinner as well. I would very much like to know what mischief Pagett was up to in Florence. Whenever Italy is mentioned, he goes to pieces. If I did not know how intensely respectable he is I should suspect him of some disreputable amou. I wonder now! Even the most respectable menIt would cheer me up enormously if it was so.

Poirot reassured her, "I also find it hard to believe, mademoiselle. Perhaps he's protecting someone." Marie's eyes narrowed. "Protecting someone? His mother, perhaps? I've always suspected her. Who stands to inherit his vast fortune? She does. And that secretary, Stonor, he's involved too. They are too close for comfort. She may be older, but men don't mind if a woman is wealthy!" Poirot intervened, "Stonor claims he was in England. But can we trust him?" Poirot then asked, "Do you know your mother's real name?" Marie broke down in tears. Poirot continued, "Did you know who M. Renauld was?" Marie looked puzzled. Poirot explained the case to her, leaving her in awe. "You are incredible. You must save him," she pleaded. The next morning, we attended Jack's interrogation. He looked worn out and desperate, as if he hadn't slept in days.

Count Foscatini’s teeth were dazzlingly white. Despite the coffee stains on the teeth, we deduce that Count Foscatini did not consume any coffee. However, all three cups contained coffee. Why would someone fabricate the idea that Count Foscatini had coffee when he did not? This puzzled me greatly. "Let me assist you. What proof do we have that Ascanio and his companion, or two imposters posing as them, actually visited the apartment that night? No one witnessed their arrival or departure. We rely solely on the accounts of one person and various inanimate objects." "Are you suggesting?" "I am referring to the cutlery, plates, and empty dishes. Graves is deceitful and cunning, yet remarkably organized! He overhears part of a conversation in the morning, realizing that Ascanio will be vulnerable. The next evening, around eight o’clock, he informs his employer of a phone call. Foscatini sits down to answer the phone, and Graves strikes him with a marble statue from behind. Following this, a dinner for three is ordered through the service phone! Graves sets the table, uses the plates, knives, and forks, etc. He even consumes the food. Despite being clever, he also has a hearty appetite! But after finishing three tournedos, the rice soufflé proves too much. He even smokes a cigar and two cigarettes for added effect. It was a meticulously planned crime! Moving the clock hands to 8.47, he breaks and stops the clock. The only oversight was leaving the curtains undrawn. But in a real dinner party, the curtains would have been closed as soon as it got dark. He then casually mentions the guests to the elevator attendant before rushing to a phone booth. Around 8.47, he calls the doctor using Foscatini's dying voice. The plan was so flawless that no one questioned if a call was made from Flat II at that time." "Except for Hercule Poirot, I assume?" I remarked sarcastically. "Not even Hercule Poirot," my companion replied with a grin. "I intend to investigate now. I needed to convince you first. But mark my words, I will be proven right; and then Japp, who I have already tipped off, can arrest the upstanding Graves. I wonder how much of the money he has squandered." Poirot's intuition was accurate, as always. Miss Violet Marsh's case provided a refreshing change from our usual tasks. "He was transported across the Channel by naval destroyer. Upon arrival at Boulogne, he was met by a vehicle from General Headquarters and one of the Commander-in-Chief’s A.D.C.s.” “And then?” “They departed from Boulogne but never reached their destination.” “What happened?” “Monsieur Poirot, it was a fake vehicle with a false A.D.C. The genuine car was discovered in a side street, with the driver and the A.D.C. securely gagged and tied up.” “And the imposter vehicle?” “Remains at large.” Poirot expressed his frustration with a gesture. “Unbelievable! Surely it cannot evade detection for long?” “That was our assumption. It appeared to be a matter of thorough investigation. That region of France is under Military Law. We were confident that the vehicle would not go unnoticed for long. The French authorities, our Scotland Yard detectives, and the military personnel are putting in every effort. It is, as you say, unbelievable but nothing has been uncovered!” Just then, a knock sounded at the door, and a young officer entered with a tightly sealed envelope which he handed to Lord Estair. “Fresh from France, sir. I brought it straight here, as per your instructions.” The Minister eagerly tore it open, and exclaimed. The officer departed. “Finally, some news! This telegram has just been deciphered. They have located the second vehicle, along with the secretary, Daniels, chloroformed, gagged, and bound, in an abandoned farm near C. He recalls nothing, except feeling something pressed against his mouth and nose from behind, and struggling to break free. The authorities are confident in the veracity of his account.” “And nothing else was found?” “No.” “Not the Prime Minister’s deceased body? Then, there is hope. But it is perplexing. Why, after an attempted shooting this morning, are they now going to such lengths to keep him alive?” Dodge shook his head. “One thing is certain. They are resolute in their efforts to prevent him from attending the Conference at any cost.” “If it is humanly feasible, the Prime Minister will be present. May God grant it is not too late. Now, gentlemen, give me a full account from the beginning. I must be informed about the shooting incident as well.” “Last night, the Prime Minister, accompanied by one of his secretaries, Captain Daniels” “The same individual who went with him to France?” “Yes. As I was saying, they drove down to Windsor, where the Prime Minister had an Audience. Early this morning, he returned to London, and it was during the journey that the attempted assassination occurred.” “One moment, if you please. Who is this Captain Daniels? Do you have his background?” Lord Estair smiled. “I anticipated you would ask that. We do not possess much information about him. He is not from a notable family. He has served in the British Army, and is a very competent secretary, with exceptional language skills. I believe he is fluent in seven languages. That is why the Prime Minister selected him to accompany him to France.” “Does he have any family in England?” “Two aunts. A Mrs. Everard, residing in Hampstead, and a Miss Daniels, living close to Ascot.” “Ascot? Isn't that near Windsor?” “That connection has not been disregarded. But it has yielded no results.” “Do you consider Capitaine Daniels to be beyond suspicion?” A touch of bitterness seeped into Lord Estair’s tone as he responded: “No, Monsieur Poirot. In this day and age, I would hesitate before declaring anyone beyond suspicion.” "Très bien."
